title.text: Automatically Assessing Whether a Text Is Clichéd, with Applications to Literary Analysis

abstractContent.text: Clichés, as trite expressions, are predominantly multiword expressions, but not all MWEs are clichés.

We conduct a preliminary examination of the problem of determining how clichéd a text is, taken as a whole, by comparing it to a reference text with respect to the proportion of more-frequent n-grams, as measured in an external corpus.
We find that more-frequent n-grams are over-represented in clichéd text.
We apply this finding to the "Eumaeus" episode of James Joyce's novel Ulysses, which literary scholars believe to be written in a deliberately clichéd style.

entities.text: Eumaeus" episode of James Joyce's novel Ulysses
